Massachusetts General Laws c.\u202f186,.proposition: This is a civil action brought by Plaintiff Olivia Martinez (“Plaintiff”) against Defendant James Houghton (“Defendant”), her landlord, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c.\u202f185C, \u00a7\u202f3.proposition: Venue and jurisdiction are proper in the Boston Housing Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the rental property that is the subject of this action is located in Suffolk County and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred there.

M.G.L. c.\u202f186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease contains an implied covenant that the tenant shall have the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f186,\u202f\u00a7\u202f.proposition: Award costs of this action, including reasonable attorney’s fees pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that substantial, ongoing noise and disturbances affecting residential tenants fall within the landlord’s implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, and that such conditions can amount to constructive eviction when they render the premises not reasonably habitable. The opinion explicitly treats the tenants’ loss of “quiet enjoyment” due to noise from a lounge as within the ambit of the covenant, even though the landlord did not subjectively intend the deprivation but had the ability to control the conditions. This directly supports the proposition that such tenancy conditions are covered by the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law and ties it to conditions of tenancy such as repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” covers serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the leased premises, and holds that repeated sewage flooding that violates sanitary code duties can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus, it supports the proposition that a tenant’s conditions of tenancy fall within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts case law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law and grounds liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It squarely recognizes such tenancy conditions (lack of required heat) as within the ambit of the statutory and common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, thereby supporting the proposition that similar conditions of tenancy fall within that covenant’s protection.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. … Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that conditions of tenancy such as pervasive criminal/drug activity in common areas, when the landlord fails to take reasonable remedial measures, can constitute a serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. The court reverses summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim and explains that loss of use of sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreational areas controlled by the landlord falls within the ambit of that covenant. Thus, it affirmatively recognizes that these conditions of tenancy are within the protection of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures…then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment at length, but it does recognize that the tenant’s problems with leaks, flooding, cockroaches, an inadequate front door that allowed an intruder, and related habitability and security issues formed the basis for counterclaims including breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) and were treated as actionable conditions of the tenancy. The court affirms the trial judge’s findings and the resulting damages under c. 93A, which were explicitly premised in part on the breach of quiet enjoyment, thereby implicitly recognizing that such tenancy conditions fall within that covenant’s ambit under Massachusetts law.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt: Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, “also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.” … On October 23, 1981, LeClair sent Brown a “demand letter” seeking damages and requesting relief (repairs) under c. 93A for problems relating to leaks, the January 31, 1980, flood, cockroaches, the assault, and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud deals exclusively with wage payment issues under the Massachusetts Wage Act and the continued availability of common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, conditions of tenancy, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a tenant’s conditions of tenancy fall within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitt v. Plaud, 466 Mass. 240 (2013).relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and whether conditions of tenancy fall within its ambit. Although the tenant in Haddad asserted a quiet-enjoyment counterclaim, the Supreme Judicial Court did not analyze or define the covenant’s scope or the conditions covered by it; the opinion’s substantive discussion focuses instead on G.L. c. 93A, emotional distress, and warranty of habitability damages. Because there is no developed reasoning about what conditions fall within the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the case does not meaningfully support the stated proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After her landlord, the plaintiff Nick Haddad, commenced a summary process action in the Housing Court for the city of Boston for nonpayment of rent, the defendant, Luz Gonzalez, filed six counterclaims alleging: (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L.c. 186, § 14 (1990 ed.); ... After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A ... We now affirm.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case directly concerns the scope of the Massachusetts statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and what kinds of conditions (here, lead paint hazards) can fall within its ambit. The SJC holds that such tenancy conditions can violate the covenant when they result from at least negligent conduct by a landlord who has notice or reason to know of the problem. Thus, although the court rejects strict-liability quiet enjoyment based solely on a statutory violation, it affirms that conditions of the tenancy, including lead hazards, are within the scope of § 14 when the fault standard is met.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses warranty of habitability, State Sanitary Code violations, and related rent abatement, but it does not analyze or even mention the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court characterizes the impact of conditions on the use and enjoyment of the apartment only in the context of habitability and damages, not in terms of the separate doctrine of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Thus, this case does not provide direct authority that the tenant’s conditions of tenancy fall within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.raw_text: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983)
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.proposition: Plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy are within the ambit of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized by Massachusetts case law, including but not limited to:
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.case_name: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.support_reasoning: The opinion is about a private college’s authority to expel a student and the validity of a release, not about landlord-tenant law or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Nowhere does the court discuss conditions of tenancy, interference with possessory rights in leased premises, or G.L. c. 186, §14 or analogous common-law quiet enjoyment principles. Thus this case does not provide authority that a plaintiff’s conditions of tenancy fall within the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.relevant_excerpt: “We dispose of this case on the ground that the college did not violate any contractual or other rights of the plaintiffs by expelling Coveney, and on the additional ground that Coveney waived the claims he asserts here by executing a valid and binding general release. A private university, college, or school may not arbitrarily or capriciously dismiss a student… If school officials act in good faith and on reasonable grounds, however, their decision to suspend or expel a student will not be subject to successful challenge in the courts.”
